Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Damage Control Laparotomy Versus Definitive Surgical Management in Trauma Patients

Background: This randomised controlled trial aimed to assess the effects of damage control laparotomy (DCL) compared to definitive surgical management (DSM) on mortality and complications in trauma patients.

Methods: Trauma patients at 12 level 1 North American trauma centers were randomised based on transfusion ratios as described in the PROPPR trial. The primary outcomes were 24-hour and 30-day mortality. A mixed-effects logistic model was used to compare DCL and DSM, with a random effect for study site. The trial included 329 patients undergoing emergent laparotomy: 213 DCL and 116 DSM. Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified. Blinding details were not provided.

Results: DCL rates varied between institutions (33%-83%, p=0.002). Median Injury Severity Score (ISS) was higher in the DCL group, 29 versus 21 (p<0.001). 24-hour mortality was 19% with DCL versus 4% (p<0.001); 30-day mortality was 28% with DCL versus 19% (p<0.001). In a mixed-effects model, ISS and major intra-abdominal vascular injury (MVI) were correlates of DCL. DCL was not associated with 30-day mortality (OR 2.33, CI 0.97-5.60). Sepsis and ventilator-associated pneumonia occurred more frequently with DCL (p<0.05). 80% of DCL patients met standard criteria.

Interpretation: Although DCL utilization varied significantly between institutions, there was no significant mortality difference between centers. This suggests that tempering DCL use may not decrease mortality but could reduce related complications.
